Award.AwardTitle: Decentralized Exchange: Theory and Market Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the last couple of decades, markets have seen a dramatic shift of trade toward new types of trading exchanges being created along with traditional, centralized, public trading venues. The shift in trade away from centralized exchanges towards these new types of decentralized trading platforms is common not only for assets and goods with units as heterogeneous as real estate, but also for assets that are similar in nature. Most bonds, foreign exchange, and more recently stocks, are traded over the counter. In addition, new types of securities such as bespoke (personalized) products are being introduced, which do not exist in centralized exchanges. The small but growing research on decentralized trading has emphasized frictions that arise due to decentralization of trade - associated with search for trading partners, information asymmetries amongst traders, or counterparty risk.
The proposed project has two broad objectives. The first is to understand the potential for decentralized markets to improve efficiency, compared to centralized trading environments. What are the economic mechanisms in decentralized markets that do not have centralized market counterparts? The second is to develop general principles for market design and product (security) design in decentralized trade settings.
The intellectual merit of this project is a deeper understanding of the functioning of decentralized markets. This research will introduce a flexible framework and equilibrium analysis for relationships and market structures that cannot be studied as graphs (bilateral links) without loss, and are more appropriately represented by a generalization of graphs known as hypergraphs.
It is expected that the techniques produced by this project will enhance practical design in high-stake applications and facilitate research by theorists studying networks as well as applied economists, statisticians, and other social scientists (academics and practitioners), and policymakers. In particular, the proposed research will develop specific recommendations concerning the functioning and regulation of markets that policymakers and market designers face in implementation of the post-crisis changes in over-the-counter markets mandated by the Dodd-Frank act.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the classical theory, markets are centralized. All units are exchanged through a single market clearing at terms of trade that apply to all agents equally. In contemporaneous markets, many types of assets are traded increasingly, or exclusively, over the counter (OTC). This holds not only for assets with units as heterogeneous as real estate but also most bonds—government, municipal, and corporate—are traded over the counter, as are asset-backed securities, derivatives, loans, and foreign exchange (e.g., Duffie (2012)). Likewise, stock trading occurs in many different trading venues. Over the past to decades, new electronic markets have also emerged that offer different types of market clearing (e.g., direct matching with an intermediary, trading in a dealer network, or an online centralized exchange) to different types of traders, institutional and retail.  Moreover, markets are decentralized simply because different participants trade different assets—by choice or regulation. To the extent that more types of trading venues and securities are being created away from open exchanges and trading volumes outside open exchanges—have increased several-fold over the past couple of decades, this suggests—efficiency gains associated with decentralization of trade. The objective of this research was to uncover the sources underlying these efficiency gains.

The early literature on decentralized trading emphasized frictions that arise due to decentralization of trade—associated with the search for trading partners, information asymmetries amongst traders, or counterparty risk. This work challenges the traditional view of fragmented markets as a friction by recognizing the potential for market fragmentation to improve efficiency.

This research introduces a framework for market structures that cannot be studied as graphs (bilateral links) without loss, and are more appropriately represented by a generalization of graphs known as hypergraphs. Using methods from the theory of the shorted operators and monotone matrix functions, this research develops comparative statics of equilibrium and welfare for decentralized markets with incomplete participation. Decentralized trading can improve the efficiency of allocation relative to the centralized market with the same traders and assets by allocating more risk towards more risk averse traders.

In the study of the formation of market structures, it is well known that accommodating complementary agreements has proven challenging. This research provides existence results for the analysis of stable outcomes in environments with complementarities, such as markets for patent licenses, differentiated products, or multi-sided platforms. These results, which rely on a novel fixed point characterization of stable outcomes, apply to both nontransferable and transferable utility settings, and allow for multilateral agreements and externalities.

The last decade has seen significant progress concerning allocation problems, in which traders seek to buy or sell multiple heterogeneous goods. Special attention has been given to a design’s ability to select a core outcome—a strong efficiency criterion and a key challenge for practical market design. Core selection ensures that no group of participants (the bidders and the auctioneer) can do better by trading on its own. Its absence leads to incentive problems that can compromise virtually any aspect of design, including efficiency, revenue, and participation. These issues are well understood in one-sided auctions (where all bidders are interested in buying) for indivisible goods. In such settings, the literature has established a close link between core selection and a goods substitutes property. In many resource allocation problems, however, bidders are interested in selling or buying various goods. Likewise, the auctioneer may specifically desire to reallocate goods among the bidders, or wish to acquire certain goods and sell others. Indeed, reallocating the spectrum controlled by television stations into uses of higher-value was part of the the objective of the most recent Federal Communications Commission in the U.S. spectrum auction. In applications like spectrum auctions, the auctioneer is not necessarily constrained to allocate each bidder a nonnegative quantity of each good; bidders may wish to switch to a different frequency or exit a market. Moreover, as is the case with spectrum, electricity, and emission permits, bidders typically have complex preferences over the goods being auctioned, and the same goods may be considered substitutes by some bidders and complements by others. This work demonstrates that heterogeneity in either pre-auction valuations of the bidders or substitution patterns in their demands can independently challenge core selection. For markets with multiple heterogeneous divisible goods, this research characterizes the possibilities and limits for a core-selecting design in such two-sided settings, such as auctions in which bidders enter with non-zero endowments of the goods auctioned, or reallocating goods among the bidders is part of the auctioneer's objective.

The techniques produced by this research suggest several ways to enhance practical design in high-stake applications, such as spectrum auctions and OTC markets. The results also demonstrate the impact of various contract design decisions, such as the application of antitrust law to disallow patent pools, on stable outcomes.
